title: Exploring musical instruments: the piano
subtitle: The musical background of the piano
description:
The aim of our story is to present some information about the piano and to look more closely at the story of one of the world's best-known pianists, Ludwig van Beethoven.

The piano is one of the most popular instruments and the most harmonically complete one but, at the same time, it is also the most challenging to master.
The piano was invented by the Italian Bartolomeo Cristofori around 1700. However, before his invention, the piano had precursors such as the clavichord, harpsichord and dulcimer. As a result of this complex evolution, the piano can be classified as a string, percussion and keyboard instrument.

dynamic_elements.text:
As far as the different types of piano are concerned, they are mainly divided into three primary categories, Grand, Upright, and Electronic, which in turn can be further sub-divided. In fact, as the search result above shows, at least 26 types of piano can be identified, a number that also includes unique pianos such as Pleyel, exhibited at the Museum of Romanticism in Madrid.

Below, you can see some pictures of prominent pianos.
The following tables show some important male and female musicians who play the piano.

To give an idea of the number and distribution of pianists around the world, the visualization in the map below is useful. From the data retrieved, it can be seen that the largest number of pianists is found in Europe, with a greater concentration in the areas between Germany and Austria.

dynamic_elements.map_points_query:
SELECT DISTINCT ?point ?pointLabel ?countryLabel ?lat ?long
WHERE {
?point wdt:P106 wd:Q486748 .
?point wdt:P27 ?country .
?country p:P625 ?statement .  
?statement psv:P625 ?node. ?node wikibase:geoLatitude ?lat ; wikibase:geoLongitude ?long.
SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". } }
LIMIT 100

dynamic_elements.text: Over the years, the talent of many outstanding pianists has produced timeless works. Below are some examples of renowned piano pieces.

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
SELECT DISTINCT ?label (COUNT(distinct ?pianist) as ?count) 
WHERE {
     ?pianist ?a wd:Q36834 . # pianist
      ?pianist wdt:P800 ?notablework . 
   
     SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en".
          ?notablework rdfs:label         ?label.
      }
}

GROUP BY ?label ?count 
ORDER BY DESC(?count)
LIMIT 10

dynamic_elements.text: As observed in the chart above, some of the most famous and important piano pieces, such as the top three Symphony No. 4, Symphony No. 1 and Symphony No. 3, were created by the pianist, composer and conductor Ludwig van Beethoven.

Beethoven was born in Bonn, Germany, in 1770 and is known as one of the most important pianists of all time. He was active in the music field from 1798 to 1827: the table below shows the most important work of the musician and composer.

dynamic_elements.chart_query:
SELECT DISTINCT (year(xsd:dateTime(?date)) as ?label) (COUNT(?label) AS ?count) 
WHERE { ?work ?a wd:Q255 . ?work wdt:P86 wd:Q255 . ?work wdt:P577 ?date . 
SERVICE wikibase:label { bd:serviceParam wikibase:language "en". ?work rdfs:label ?label. }
      } 
GROUP BY ?count ?date 
ORDER BY ?label 
LIMIT 30
